Alicia Witt stars as Alice Chapman - an antique shop owner: the shop passed down to her from her father along with her love of antiques. She is dating an up and coming property developer who is working for a company anxious to get ahold of the land that just so happens to have Witt's store as a part of - and she is a definite 'No Sale'. What is a manipulative boyfriend to do but to have her convinced of his devotion to her, his doting upscale life spread all about hers and with the next step, he would like her to meet his parents...finally. She feels the two are in-sync and the perfect match although as the story progresses, we soon see she has put her whole life's dreams on hold for another.

In a mixed-up meeting at the airport, unaccompanied by her fiance, she meets someone she believes is related to him directly by name and goes home with him. Believing she is meeting the whole wonderful family as expected. She is overjoyed with the likenesses they share and the new relationships she makes, one in particular. As the title implies, this is a mix-up on several accounts that she hasn't a clue of while having the Christmas time of her life... until reality sets in.

This movie actually teaches a great lesson about putting aside your own values, traditions, and ideas for another while not even realizing the compromises you have slowly made. Is she able to catch this in time or can her fiance, who is a master manipulator, overplease her with everything that he can offer? This film spans home cooking to homewrecking and everything tossed into a great Christmas eye-candy Hallmark Movie.

The overall story was cute-ish. I didn't really have an issue with the actors either.  The problem with this film was the script.  The story was never going to be amazing, but there was simply too many places where the dialogue was stilted and simply didn't sound the way real people speak.  There were scenes where the actions of the characters were too childish for the age the characters were supposed to be.

I get that this is a Hallmark Holiday movie, but it's definitely story-lite.  There's a not a lot of story to the story.  What little plot there was seemed to be vaguely reminiscent of "While You Were Sleeping".  Although there's no comatose brother, there's misunderstanding of a family who thinks the main character is engaged to a son who apparently doesn't have a great deal of contact with his sibling (and this doesn't work very well, as it was odd that no one in the family thought to call "Billy" to find out what was going on).  One brother is a businessman, while the other is someone who builds furniture. Instead of the semi-cantankerous next door neighbor, there's a grandfather.  The problem is there's not enough of a story to tell here.  I can almost picture pages of the script with minimal dialogue and stage directions that say "Act playful and cute" (hence the "making cookies" scene).  Even with a better script, this still would not have been Citizen Kane, but it would have given the actors something better to work with.  There were a few places that were so saccharine as to be embarrassing.

I love Christmas movies, but this is on my list of top 10 favorites. I don't know if it's the story itself or the chemistry between the two actors that make it what it is, and that is a simple sweet old fashioned kind of love story.
Now, there is the classic jerk, the odd ball in-laws to be, and the quirkiness that make the equation of this movie, but each of those elements add to the sweetness of the main characters and their story.

I am mystified by the high rating for this incredibly mediocre movie.  Alicia Witt carries the movie as well as an one actor possibly could, but that is all it has going for it.  There is NO chemistry between any of the characters and the story is unrealistic even for a Christmas movie.

Matt is just strange and awkward in every way.  There is nothing in the story to suggest why Alice would be attracted to him.  Though Matt's family is clearly warm and welcoming to Alice, there is no character development.  I have no idea who they are or what makes them tick.  They are bland.

There are many parallels between this story and "While You Were Sleeping" but a world of difference in the way that it is presented.  This movie fails on so many levels that it is hard to know where to start.

The characters tell us what they care about but there is no real evidence in their actions.  The dialog is trite and silly in many ways.  The photography leaves a lot to be desired.  The scenes are incomplete.  The place with the ice sculptures is a mystery to me.  Where is it relative to the town?  Why is Matt the only person there?  What does the area actually look like  we only see a glimpse of it.  What happened to the car that crashed?  Why would anyone turn down $3.5 Million just for sentimental reasons when they are struggling to survive?

This is a nice Hallmark Christmas movie that follows a fairly common script for romantic movies, albeit with a somewhat unique twist in the middle. This one is the story of a woman who owns an antique shop that is under threat of a buyout and her fiancee who is a successful real estate guy. They are supposed to visit his family for Christmas but end up travelling separately because he needs to wrap up a deal. Along the way, she has a number of mishaps in the airport that lead to her going home with her fiancee's brother which leads to a car accident. It's pretty clear from early in the movie that she will end up with the brother and not her fiancee who appears not to be her type from the start. The girl and the brother have nice chemistry in the movie and there are some other likeable characters. Unfortunately some of the romantic spark and payoff are obscured by repetitious scenes between the girl and her fiancee. This isn't one of the best Hallmark Christmas movies I have seen, but it is a pretty good one and worth watching if you like these kinds of movies.

This farcical Christmas romance works overtime to infuse the predictable story with highly manufactured scenes of calculating sentiment.  There isn't a genuine moment to be had amongst all the manipulative plotting and the cheat of coincidences that lays this story bare.
A woman named Alice (Alicia Witt) is sent by her workaholic boyfriend to meet his parents for the holidays.  Through a series of obvious contrivances, she loses her luggage, kills her phone, and supposedly just happens to run into her brother-in-law to be, who almost kills them in a car accident.  He takes her home where she insinuates herself into his family.  The mistake isn't discovered until his brother shows up and proves to be a total stranger.  They're all strangers.  But gee, didn't they have a lovely time playing at being a family.  Once the unbelievable mistake is rectified, and she finds herself with the right family, they prove to be more than a little certifiably nuts.  Could this impending marriage be an even bigger mistake!?  Will she trade one artificial relationship for another?  Merry Christmas, why not.

Whether or not you will like this movie will depend entirely on whether or not you can accept the bizarre set of circumstances driving this romance, and whether or not you can appreciate the actors playing these cardboard characters.

I found this movie to be a passable diversion (that I might consider watching again some time in the far distant Christmas future).  Otherwise, eh, I've seen better.

This is an adorable movie that points out how important family is, especially at Christmas time, and how different some families can be. I saw this when they showed it during "Christmas in July" and immediately put it on my list of "must haves." When it was released I ordered it to add to my own collection.

I've only seen this one once but I found it outstanding in a number of ways.  For one thing, Alicia Witt was outstanding -- she sparkled and I loved the emotions she showed in her face.  Alright, corny, but that's the best way to state it simply.
  It begins with her character, Alice, very happily running the antique shop that she inherited from her father when he died.  Her boyfriend, soon to be fiancee, is the polar opposite of Alice:  she's a romantic, loves family things, old things, and isn't sure she wants to sell some of the things she has in her shop, though her business isn't doing well.  Her fiancee is a salesman, born to it and you get the impression that he can't imagine anything in the world that doesn't have a price tag on it and one that he's put there for a sizable profit. As soon as she says yes to his marriage proposal you know they're in trouble.
  This is not so much a comedy, though (as always) there are some funny spots.  It's up to fate to get them out of this marriage that has "star-crossed" all over it.  I won't ruin the story by telling you any more, but I will say that the title is very appropriate -- there are some very nice twists and turns along the way. It's a lovely journey and the entire package -- acting, scenery, storyline -- are a treat.  Hallmark usually manages this kind of thing well and this movie is no exception.
